name: 1575_A. Another Sorting Problem
description:
Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books. Each book is represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, each with length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending, while Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds:

  * if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; 
  * if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b. 

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4

Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books, with each book represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n. Each book has a title that is represented by a string of length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending. On the other hand, Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds: if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4


-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.

Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books, with each book represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n. Each book has a title of a certain length. This title is represented by a string of a certain length. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending. On the other hand, Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds: if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books, with each book represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n, and each book has a title that is represented by a string of length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending. On the other hand, Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds: if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4


-------
Important Note: You must follow the input output format. Input must be taken from standard input and output must be given to standard output. The code will be tested against multiple test cases and all the test cases must be passed.
completion:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles
    books = data[1:n+1]
    
    # Define a custom key function for sorting
    def custom_key(title):
        # Create a tuple of characters with custom sorting logic
        return tuple(
            (c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)))  # Ascending for odd, descending for even
            for i, c in enumerate(title)
        )
    
    # Sort the books using the custom key
    sorted_indices = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: custom_key(books[i]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices (1-based)
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_indices))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the input
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    books = data[1:n+1]
    
    # Define a custom key function for sorting
    def custom_key(book):
        # Create a tuple of characters with custom sorting logic
        return tuple(
            (ord(book[i]) if i % 2 == 0 else -ord(book[i]))
            for i in range(m)
        )
    
    # Sort the books using the custom key
    sorted_books = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: custom_key(books[i]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted books
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_books))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles and store them with their original indices
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def custom_sort_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a tuple of characters with odd positions sorted ascending
        # and even positions sorted descending
        return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))
    
    # Sort the books using the custom sort key
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=custom_sort_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted books
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Print the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def custom_sort_key(s):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    return tuple((ord(c) if i % 2 == 0 else -ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(s))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    titles = data[2:n+2]
    
    # Pair each title with its original index
    indexed_titles = list(enumerate(titles, start=1))
    
    # Sort using the custom sort key
    indexed_titles.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[1]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices
    sorted_indices = [index for index, _ in indexed_titles]
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

main()

def custom_sort_key(s):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(s)))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    
    # Read the book titles
    books = [(data[i + 2], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Sort the books using the custom sort key
    books.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[0]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted books
    result = [str(book[1]) for book in books]
    print(" ".join(result))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

# [core concept]
    'asc-desc-ending'
    Explanation: This refers to the sorting order where odd-indexed characters are sorted in ascending order and even-indexed characters are sorted in descending order.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    No phrase showing quantity relationship

    No degree adverb

# [code logic]
    The steps in the custom sorting function should be implemented simultaneously. Specifically, the comparison of characters based on their odd or even positions should be handled within a single comparison function. This can be done using a loop that iterates over the character positions and applies the appropriate comparison logic based on the position's parity.

# [edge case] 
    Input: 1 1
           A
    Output: 1
    Explanation: With only one book, the sorted order is trivially the same as the input order.

    Input: 2 2
           AA
           AB
    Output: 1 2
    Explanation: The first character is odd-indexed and the same for both titles, so we move to the second character which is even-indexed. 'A' comes after 'B' in descending order, so 'AA' comes before 'AB'.

    Input: 3 3
           ABC
           BAC
           CAB
    Output: 1 2 3
    Explanation: The first character is odd-indexed, 'A' comes before 'B' and 'C', so 'ABC' comes first. Then 'BAC' comes before 'CAB' because 'B' comes before 'C' in ascending order.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of sorting based on the custom comparison function will naturally handle these cases.

Please read and understand the following inteperation before coding
# [core concept]
    'lexicographically ascending' and 'lexicographically descending'
    Explanation: Lexicographical order is the order in which words or strings are arranged in a dictionary. Ascending means from A to Z, and descending means from Z to A.

    'asc-desc-endingly'
    Explanation: This is a custom sorting order where odd-indexed characters are sorted in ascending order and even-indexed characters are sorted in descending order.

# [phrase showing quantity relationship]
    No specific phrases showing quantity relationships are present in the requirement.

# [degree adverb]
    No degree adverbs are present in the requirement.

# [code logic]
    The steps in the plan related to defining the custom sorting function should be implemented simultaneously. Specifically, the steps:
    - "Create a function that takes two strings a and b."
    - "Iterate over each character position i from 0 to m-1."
    - "If i is odd, compare the characters at position i in a and b lexicographically ascending."
    - "If i is even, compare the characters at position i in a and b lexicographically descending."
    These steps should be implemented in a single function that handles the comparison logic.

# [edge case]
    1. Input: 1 1 \n A
       Output: 1
       Explanation: With only one book, the order remains the same.
       
    2. Input: 2 2 \n AA \n AB
       Output: 1 2
       Explanation: Both books have the same first character, and the second character is compared descendingly, so 'AA' comes before 'AB'.

    3. Input: 3 3 \n ABC \n ACB \n BAC
       Output: 2 1 3
       Explanation: The first character is the same for the first two books, so the second character is compared descendingly. For the third book, the first character is different and is compared ascendingly.

# [extra code for edge case]
    We do not need extra code to handle the edge cases. The original logic of the custom sorting function should handle these cases correctly.

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles and store them with their original indices
    books = [(data[i + 1], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Define the custom comparator function
    def custom_sort_key(book):
        title, index = book
        # Create a tuple of characters with odd positions sorted ascending
        # and even positions sorted descending
        return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c))) for i, c in enumerate(title))
    
    # Sort the books using the custom sort key
    sorted_books = sorted(books, key=custom_sort_key)
    
    # Extract the indices of the sorted books
    sorted_indices = [index for _, index in sorted_books]
    
    # Print the result
    print(' '.join(map(str, sorted_indices)))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def custom_sort_key(s):
    # Create a tuple that represents the custom sort order
    # Odd-indexed characters are sorted ascending, even-indexed descending
    return tuple((c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)) for i, c in enumerate(s)))

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().split()
    
    n = int(data[0])
    m = int(data[1])
    
    # Read the book titles
    books = [(data[i + 2], i + 1) for i in range(n)]
    
    # Sort the books using the custom sort key
    books.sort(key=lambda x: custom_sort_key(x[0]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted books
    result = [str(book[1]) for book in books]
    print(" ".join(result))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles
    books = data[1:n+1]
    
    # Sort the books using the custom sort key
    sorted_indices = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: custom_sort_key(books[i]))
    
    # Output the indices of the sorted book titles (1-based index)
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_indices))

Round_0.code:
def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the next n lines to get the list of book titles
    books = data[1:n+1]
    
    # Define a custom key function for sorting
    def custom_key(s):
        # Create a tuple of characters with custom sorting logic
        return tuple(
            (c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)))  # Ascending for odd, descending for even
            for i, c in enumerate(s)
        )
    
    # Sort the books using the custom key
    sorted_indices = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: custom_key(books[i]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices (1-based)
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_indices))

if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

def main():
    import sys
    input = sys.stdin.read
    data = input().splitlines()
    
    # Parse the first line to get n and m
    n, m = map(int, data[0].split())
    
    # Parse the book titles
    books = data[1:n+1]
    
    # Define a custom key function for sorting
    def custom_key(title):
        # Create a tuple of characters with custom sorting logic
        return tuple(
            (c if i % 2 == 0 else chr(255 - ord(c)))  # Ascending for odd, descending for even
            for i, c in enumerate(title)
        )
    
    # Sort the books using the custom key
    sorted_indices = sorted(range(n), key=lambda i: custom_key(books[i]))
    
    # Output the sorted indices (1-based)
    print(' '.join(str(i + 1) for i in sorted_indices))

if __name__ == "__main__":

prompt:
Andi and Budi were given an assignment to tidy up their bookshelf of n books, with each book represented by the book title — a string s_i numbered from 1 to n. Each book has a title that is represented by a string of length m. Andi really wants to sort the book lexicographically ascending. On the other hand, Budi wants to sort it lexicographically descending.

Settling their fight, they decided to combine their idea and sort it asc-desc-endingly, where the odd-indexed characters will be compared ascendingly, and the even-indexed characters will be compared descendingly.

A string a occurs before a string b in asc-desc-ending order if and only if in the first position where a and b differ, the following holds: if it is an odd position, the string a has a letter that appears earlier in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b; if it is an even position, the string a has a letter that appears later in the alphabet than the corresponding letter in b.

Input

The first line contains two integers n and m (1 ≤ n ⋅ m ≤ 10^6).

The i-th of the next n lines contains a string s_i consisting of m uppercase Latin letters — the book title. The strings are pairwise distinct.

Output

Output n integers — the indices of the strings after they are sorted asc-desc-endingly.

Example

Input


5 2
AA
AB
BB
BA
AZ


Output


5 2 1 3 4
